number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												This was a fantastic game back in the day of the PS2 era, still is to be honest. It's great when Rock star bring their games to pc, *Cough* Red Dead Redemption *Cough*.So with Bully being developed by beloved RockStar, it was designed from the same vein as GTA...but with kids...and no guns...or killing. Not necessary a major drag, you just get to run around with a super powered slingshot, stink bombs and fire crackers to really annoy people.The game is based around a 15 year kid called Jimmy Hopkins, who is transferred to a boarding school because his mum wanted to go on a 12+ month holiday. Lucky her, eh? So you're the new kid, and you need to work your way up the ranks to be at the top of the school. So naturally no one respects or fears you to start with, even the nerds of the school. So you do the usual mission progression and go through the chapters, which are pretty much like school terms, and you work for different school groups to gain their respect and trust.That's pretty much the jist of the game, other than that it's got you're typical collectables hunt, garage full of vehicles (in this case it's push bikes), shops selling you goods to help you with your carnage, and mini games to help you earn extra cash / abilities.The mini games are kinda fun and can completed fairly quickly. You've got your class room mini games and your 'earn some do$h' mini games. The cash ones are typical teenager jobs, such as a paper route or mowing lawns. But with the class room mini games they help improve Jimmy's abilities, such as chemistry lessons help buff up your chemistry set to create more useful and powerful prank tools. Auto shop gives you better push bikes, English helps you pick up the ladies ;D and so on. The class room mini games can essentially be completed in the first chapter, so no more lessons for the whole year! If only...*Sigh*Quite a lengthy game, if you go for 100% completion. The story is a bit meh and generic, like it's been done in a way before in previous RockStar game. Not going to give too many spoilers now! You'll just have to play and find out ;)  Then again, I could be completely getting one of the GTA games plots all wrong in my head, I hope not.But there are some good moments in the story with memorable, and stereo typical, characters you expect from a US school. Can't say I can really relate to be honest, British high school life is waaaaaaaay different. Thanks for butchering the spirit of The Inbetweeners, USA...An annoying factor to the game is the restriction at night where you can't be out of your dorm past 8 pm, other wise you get chased by the never sleeping prefects and police. If you're out after 2 or 3 am, you automatically get knocked out and appear in your dorm for 8 am. So you can't be a crazy kid and never sleep, ever.I do have to you warn you though, since this was a console port to the PC the controls aren't 100% perfect. So I recommend playing with a controller. Not the keyboard & Mouse!Over all the game isn't too bad, defiantly worth picking up if you have nostalgic feelings towards this game. I know I did, and didn't regret it! :DIn conclusion:  Fairly decent graphics from the PS2 era.  Good story, the game is quite lengthy if you also do the side content.  Excellent alternative to the GTA series, if you're looking for a less violent game.  Plenty of side content to keep a completionist busy for a few hours.  Fun character clothing customising. Make Jimmy look like a right ponce.  Fairly big open world.  Irritating in game hours, in which you have only so many to do stuff in.  Poor port to PC, use a game pad rather than a keyboard & mouse.7 / 10 Get the Go-Kart asap, other wise you won't be able to run the old ladies over fast enough before they dive out of the way.

												I remember putting this game into my PS2 way back when thinking it would just be Grand Theft Auto in a school. But boy was I happy that I was wrong. Everything about Bully, whether it be its characters, atmosphere, or even its soundtrack, just gives it way more personality than some Grand Theft Autos. When I saw it on the Summer Sale, I got without hesitation and started my journey through Bullworth Academy for my 4th time. The only complaint I have with the game is that the towns outside of the school never feel as fleshed out or interesting. But that and minor glitches aside, Bully is a fenominal game. And if you have a controller nearby to use, Bully: Scholarship Edition is a fenominal port.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												A good, solid game with a lot of charm. However, just like it's protagonist, it's rough around the edges and lacks what is needed for it to be great. When people say it's kinda like GTA in school enviroment, they're right. It's kinda like GTA. Unlike GTA, you're somewhat limited by the school system and time, because you can only do certain things at certain time, but the time flies by quickly and so does the tempo of this game. You're constantly on the move, doing a lot of smaller missions and try to fit them to your daily routine, which is not a bad thing, but a lot of missions are really primitive, especially compared to GTA. Many of them are creative, so you won't be getting bored, I just wish we perhaps had less and more fleshed out ones. You can of course slow down, doing less every day and just fart around, but it can be frustrating, knowing you have to commit truancy to finish a mission, when you want to go to class so you can get a nice upgrade (passing at least some classes is adviced, others give you crap like different clothes you'll likely never wear out of embarrasement).Bully has a lot going for it, but it has some drawbacks, making it somewhat difficult to recommend to everyone. First off, the obvious - poor PC conversion. You will not have a good time playing this with keyboard and mouse. A gamepad is a must. Second, the controls are sometimes very loose and inprecise, plus the autoaiming system when you fight somebody is downright broken, on multiple occasions it targeted an ally, or target that was much further than the one I actually wanted to attack. Also, I really had an issue with a camera, not only it likes to fly around like crazy, but the default view is almost sitting on the ground, not like in any GTA, where it flies over your shoulder. Here, I found myself constantly battling against it.The game has a decent lenght, but it pales compared to GTA. It's by no means short game, but I couldn't help wishing for more - spending more time with certain characters, longer missions and better main story, which is rather weak to be honest, not that it's bad, there are many great moments, but it's somewhat overshadowed by smaller and isolated encounters with weird inhabitants of Bullworth. You meet a lot of hillarious characters once or twice, and then they just fade away, or maybe you'll bump into them randomly, and that's kinda it. Not that it's dissapointing, once again, I just wish there was more, because this settings has so much potential. The main protagonist is kinda underdeveloped, he doesn't have that much character going for and sometimes does questionable things without questioning them at all, when just few seconds before he was pretty vocal about it.With that out of the way, Bully is worth your time. For a great price, there is every school steteotype imaginable, it's all filled to the top with great humor. Dialogues are fantastic, characters are fantastic (although you spend way less time with those that are really interesting, and there is very little character development, again, probably due to the more arcady nature of the game), the atmosphere is fantastic and despite you being limited to much smaller area than San Andreas for example, it's packed with stuff to do. I've especially liked that weather changes as you go through whole year and so does appearance of everything. I don't think there are many games from school enviroment, but I'm willing to bet there aren't any that have open world and are this funny. It is a miracle that we even got this game, and even though it's flawed and lacking, it puts an evil grin on my face.// Also, outdoor graphics are strangely muddy and blurred, there is some rather unfortunate effect applied there, and it doesn't happen indoors. Because of that, when you first start the game, you'll immediatelly feel like something is wrong, and that perhaps you have a wrong resolution. No, it's the game, either a weird design decision, or another bug.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												I played this all the way through on the Xbox 360 Edition, Since I don't play consoles anymore, I picked this up for the PC when it was on sale.The game itself is really great, especially considering when it came out. The graphics have certainly aged, though they were good for their time. The gameplay itself is very unique, you get weapons which you'd expect a schoolyard deviant to have, like a slingshot, spud gun, etc. Plus, you have to perform minigames to do well in your classes. Despite your character's deviant nature, it actually will help you to advance in each class, giving you things like new ways to interact with people socially, new outfits, eventually new bikes, and in the science class, new, unique weapons.The Story is pretty long and you'll find yourself having a good, lengthy gameplay expirience, not to even begin with all the side-stuff and optional stuff you can do. But basically, as a new kid, you're trying to make as many allies as possible with all of the social groups at bullworth academy. I'm not going to say more because I don't want to spoil anything, but it's a good story nonetheless and one to be expected from a dysfunctional academy of sorts.At first the world feels a bit limited, but that's only as you're getting the ropes of things, once the town opens up, the world is actually a pretty good size, and like I said before, there is a fair amount to do, especially when the town opens up. There also is a curfew, if you're not back in your dorm by a certain time, you can get in trouble with the prefects or the police, and if you don't get back to school in time, you can even pass out and lose your shoes or some other items.While the game is good, the PC port is very lacking, I can't even get it to do 1080p right on one monitor without part of the picture disappearing and/or stretching out to the other monitor. There's also a pretty limited amount of graphics options, however, one thing to keep in mind too is that this game is several years old, and computers back then couldn't handle what the ones of today can.Overall, if you still after all these years haven't tried it, I would highly reccomend it, it's a great, full game that has a lot on offer and you will likely not be dissappointed. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												     Probably Rockstar's best game. There isn't anything that really needs to be said about this game other than that it's just game, no stupid tutorials, no unnecessary features, it is just done well with just the right amount of stuff. Not only that, it follows a really unique gameplay style (more kid friendly than their edgy Manhunt too) which is pretty fun to play, a nice story that actually shows how bad bullying is and shows Jimmy being rewarded for being a "good" character, and a great port to the PC. This doesn't really need to be mentioned, but there isn't any problem with controls, or any bugs, or any problems at all, it does every really well and it feels really nice on PC. If you need me to describe what makes this game so good I will easily describe what makes this game so good (since there is a lot).This game's story is just great. There is so much to it and it is so great. It's all about characterization, but still manages to focus on gameplay and problems in the game world. Each chapter shows you gaining the respect of each clique, while showing you not only what their stereotypical clique is, but what each character there is like, which can be pretty funny, or if not, interesting to listen to. I don't think there is any part where I was really bored, which is great. There are also side missions which typically are teachers asking you to do things for them, and are actually somewhat linear themselves. These missions really give you an idea of what the people are like in this game in the background, and gives you a whole world to immerse yourself in. It really does well with the immersion, especially with just how humorous the world is (it's showing that the whole world is almost literally out to get him, and that not only are the teachers idiots, drunks, or evil, but the kids are essentially stereotypes who aren't interesting, but interesting at the same time, something you have to love about this game). Overall, it's really a great experience that you'd have to see for yourself on why it's so great.The gameplay style is pretty interesting too since you play as a 15 year old in a really bad school and neighborhood. There isn't any killing or weapons, and because of that, it focuses more on melee combat and combos, and special stuff like eggs and stink bombs. Other than the combat, there are still stores and an open world like GTA, just a lot smaller, so you focus more on using the map to your advantage and experiencing the importance of each area. Also, there are fun minigames like the Challenges for save points and the Carnival, which both reward you with cool stuff. If nothing else, it's a pretty worthwhile experience just because it's something new, but it's a lot more than that.Overall, this game is a lot of fun and definitely worth paying even full price for. You'll definitely get your money out of this and more. I really can't describe anything more than that so for the best idea of what this game is about you'll have to play it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												I played this all the way through on the Xbox 360 Edition, Since I don't play consoles anymore, I picked this up for the PC when it was on sale.The game itself is really great, especially considering when it came out. The graphics have certainly aged, though they were good for their time. The gameplay itself is very unique, you get weapons which you'd expect a schoolyard deviant to have, like a slingshot, spud gun, etc. Plus, you have to perform minigames to do well in your classes. Despite your character's deviant nature, it actually will help you to advance in each class, giving you things like new ways to interact with people socially, new outfits, eventually new bikes, and in the science class, new, unique weapons.The Story is pretty long and you'll find yourself having a good, lengthy gameplay expirience, not to even begin with all the side-stuff and optional stuff you can do. But basically, as a new kid, you're trying to make as many allies as possible with all of the social groups at bullworth academy. I'm not going to say more because I don't want to spoil anything, but it's a good story nonetheless and one to be expected from a dysfunctional academy of sorts.At first the world feels a bit limited, but that's only as you're getting the ropes of things, once the town opens up, the world is actually a pretty good size, and like I said before, there is a fair amount to do, especially when the town opens up. There also is a curfew, if you're not back in your dorm by a certain time, you can get in trouble with the prefects or the police, and if you don't get back to school in time, you can even pass out and lose your shoes or some other items.While the game is good, the PC port is very lacking, I can't even get it to do 1080p right on one monitor without part of the picture disappearing and/or stretching out to the other monitor. There's also a pretty limited amount of graphics options, however, one thing to keep in mind too is that this game is several years old, and computers back then couldn't handle what the ones of today can.Overall, if you still after all these years haven't tried it, I would highly reccomend it, it's a great, full game that has a lot on offer and you will likely not be dissappointed. 8.5/10

												Bully is essentially GTA in a school setting. number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												     Probably Rockstar's best game. There isn't anything that really needs to be said about this game other than that it's just game, no stupid tutorials, no unnecessary features, it is just done well with just the right amount of stuff. Not only that, it follows a really unique gameplay style (more kid friendly than their edgy Manhunt too) which is pretty fun to play, a nice story that actually shows how bad bullying is and shows Jimmy being rewarded for being a "good" character, and a great port to the PC. This doesn't really need to be mentioned, but there isn't any problem with controls, or any bugs, or any problems at all, it does every really well and it feels really nice on PC. If you need me to describe what makes this game so good I will easily describe what makes this game so good (since there is a lot).This game's story is just great. There is so much to it and it is so great. It's all about characterization, but still manages to focus on gameplay and problems in the game world. Each chapter shows you gaining the respect of each clique, while showing you not only what their stereotypical clique is, but what each character there is like, which can be pretty funny, or if not, interesting to listen to. I don't think there is any part where I was really bored, which is great. There are also side missions which typically are teachers asking you to do things for them, and are actually somewhat linear themselves. These missions really give you an idea of what the people are like in this game in the background, and gives you a whole world to immerse yourself in. It really does well with the immersion, especially with just how humorous the world is (it's showing that the whole world is almost literally out to get him, and that not only are the teachers idiots, drunks, or evil, but the kids are essentially stereotypes who aren't interesting, but interesting at the same time, something you have to love about this game). Overall, it's really a great experience that you'd have to see for yourself on why it's so great.The gameplay style is pretty interesting too since you play as a 15 year old in a really bad school and neighborhood. There isn't any killing or weapons, and because of that, it focuses more on melee combat and combos, and special stuff like eggs and stink bombs. Other than the combat, there are still stores and an open world like GTA, just a lot smaller, so you focus more on using the map to your advantage and experiencing the importance of each area. Also, there are fun minigames like the Challenges for save points and the Carnival, which both reward you with cool stuff. If nothing else, it's a pretty worthwhile experience just because it's something new, but it's a lot more than that.Overall, this game is a lot of fun and definitely worth paying even full price for. You'll definitely get your money out of this and more. I really can't describe anything more than that so for the best idea of what this game is about you'll have to play it.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												First of all, it crashes every 10-15 minutes on Windows 10 with no warning whatsoever and there's no real fix anywhere.  I've tried the "fixed" exe, running as administrator, Windows XP compatibility mode, everything.  Still crashes constantly.  For that reason I can't recommend it.As for the game itself, this is a console game and it almost certainly should be played with an Xbox 360/One controller.  It will will work with KB/M but it's awkard.  Being a console game, there aren't a lot of video options.  Unfortunately the game is locked at 30 fps, but if you've played the original Bully then there you go.The gameplay is fun, simple, and engaging.  The soundtrack is oustanding, and luckily the Steam version comes with the soundtrack as well.  The non-music sounds in the game are fairly low quality.  It has a pretty strong story mode.  If it gets fixed, I would highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												First of all, it crashes every 10-15 minutes on Windows 10 with no warning whatsoever and there's no real fix anywhere.  I've tried the "fixed" exe, running as administrator, Windows XP compatibility mode, everything.  Still crashes constantly.  For that reason I can't recommend it.As for the game itself, this is a console game and it almost certainly should be played with an Xbox 360/One controller.  It will will work with KB/M but it's awkard.  Being a console game, there aren't a lot of video options.  Unfortunately the game is locked at 30 fps, but if you've played the original Bully then there you go.The gameplay is fun, simple, and engaging.  The soundtrack is oustanding, and luckily the Steam version comes with the soundtrack as well.  The non-music sounds in the game are fairly low quality.  It has a pretty strong story mode.  If it gets fixed, I would highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												Two quick things to note before you purchase Bully: Scholarship Edition: 1. The game runs at 30fps natively (Whoop de doo, but apparently this is an issue for some people.)2.  An XBox 360 pad or 360 pad emulating software is highly recommended to play this game properly. Other configurations can work, but it works best with 360-styled controls.Anyway...Bully: Scholarship Edition is a 2008 upgrade of the 2006 PS2 game, so don't expect a lot of the bells and whistles that open world games of today have, and even in scale it's much smaller than Rockstar's other PS2 offerings. The smaller scale works in Bully's favor however, as the world is much easier to navigate and able to breathe a bit more. In the game you'll spend your time juggling your school studies alongside completing various missions to advance the story and curry favor with the various cliques around campus. Mission structures are fairly simple and easy to execute and have a certain charm to them given the high school setting. Blowing up toilets with firecrackers, dropping stink bombs in lockers, and rolling teachers down a hill an a locked porta potty are a lot more charming than the typical Rockstar fare of "Go here, shoot dudes, now go here." There's still a bit of open-world repetition to the process, but the story missions are varied enough and the scholastic mini-games fun enough that tedium rarely sets in. Narratively, Bully is more a comedy than most open-world games. There are quite a few genuine laugh oud loud lines and moments that make seeing the story through a worthwhile endeavor. Though the story and characters are brilliantly acted, they're unfortunately not written quite as well as they should be and the overall narrative and anti-bullying messages end up muddled. The main antagonist only appears in the opening and final chapters and the climax feels very slapdash and out of nowhere. With as strong as the Grand Theft Auto PS2 games were in this department, it's a bit of a bummer that Bully ended up getting a bit of a short stick. All that said, if you missed Bully the first time around, it's certainly worth a look. There's enough charm, comedy, fun things to get into, and great acting to keep the tedium of an overworld game from creeping up too often, just be aware that the payoff might not be exactly what you were hoping for.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Bully: Scholarship EditionPositives:+ A really fun open world game, where you play as a bully named Jimmy Hopkins. You can learn some really cool fight moves, use slingshots, stink bombs, itching powder, spud guns and throw eggs at people..there's many, many more items than that. This game has a comical and serious feel to it which is great.+ The storyline is interesting and you get to interact with the stereotypical school groups, such as jocks, preps and nerds. + You can attend school throughout the game or skip it, but there's numerous activities to complete in each class, many of which are enjoyable. There are a lot of small errands to complete and collectibles to find.+ I liked the style of the graphics. Even though they are not amazing for the time period, they're nice.Negatives:- The map size feels adequate when playing, but it takes a moment to realise it's quite small, especially for a Rockstar game. This is where Bully could have been improved. A bigger map, with even more to do and see. The exploration in this game is fine, but it could be enhanced.- Lack of quality side missions. You can participate in errands, but they don't have any plot background and the rewards aren't exactly useful. Bully: Scholarship Edition would benefit from deeper story-based distractions and side missions, extending the gameplay time. Which leads me to my final point.- The game is fairly short, it took me approximately 25 hours to finish which I suppose isn't too bad, but it's not quite long enough for an open world game.Overall Score: 7.5/10Bully: Scholarship Edition is awesome fun. It's a game that has been largely forgotten with time, but definitely worth picking up.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Review: Bully: Scholarship EditionThis is an Honest ReviewPROS➦ Open world style Small Town➦ Many activities for the player to do➦ No guns, no drugs. Just classic ways to fight.➦ It doesn't have the GTA style gameplay, you can't drive cars, you drive bikes. You can get busted at school for breaking school rules instead of killing people.➦ Good balance between slow pacing and fast paced action scenes.CONS➦ It is indeed a bit dated.➦ Odd selection of keys for certain actions (Using Left Alt to confirm things?)➦ You cannot edit most settings while in game, only on the main menu.MY RATING: 7.5/10DO I RECOMMEND IT: Yes!

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												I've enjoyed Rockstar Games' 'Grand Theft Auto' series ever since the release of 'Grand Theft Auto: Vice City'. I thought they did a great job technically with their game engines and stylistically with the visual designs. Plus, 'Grand Theft Auto' games are great satire of the crime film/game genre and of contemporary society for the most part. While aware of the negative impact the games can have on society and the younger generation of gamers, I still defend the merits of 'Grand Theft Auto' games.I was pretty stoked when I first read about 'Bully' back in 2005/2006, but was disappointed that the first iteration would not come to the PC platform. About a decade later, I finally got my hands on the remastered version of the game, thinking that Rockstar had injected similar type of technical and stylistic mastery, and social acuity into crafting this game as they did with 'Grand Theft Auto'. Was I wrong. True, in the year 2015, the game engine that runs 'Bully' will definitely show its age; I can accept that. However, 'Bully: Scholarship Edition' looks and sounds very uneven in spite of the remastering. The keyboard and mouse controls for the PC also feel unoptimized.The truth is, I just can't recommend 'Bully: Scholarship Edition'. It simply lacks the energy, fire and humour that I enjoy in 'Grand Theft Auto' games. The setting of Bullworth Academy, while well-designed, just doesn't seem to allow for much exploration. It feels too confined and claustrophobic even when compared to 'Grand Theft Auto: Vice City', which was released in 2002. Most importantly, 'Bully' doesn't play or feel like a satire. It is pretty much a straight-up (private) school simulator full of cliques and stereotypes with uninspired early missions.While you may approach 'Bully' and complete missions with good intentions, and that your character implicitly dislikes being bullied, you ironically need to be a bully to accomplish your goals. The unsatirical tone of 'Bully' actually makes me feel horrible for my heinous actions in the game. While I can find some reason to justify my undertaking of violent acts in 'Grand Theft Auto', I find my actions and bullying in 'Bully' to be distasteful.In the end, I guess where 'Bully' fails is that it is too real. Whereas the action sequences, violence and set pieces in 'Grand Theft Auto' were designed to be cinematic, grandiose and hyperbolic -- making the games rather hyper-realistic, all the bullying and hijinx in 'Bully' are mostly possible and hit too close to home for comfort. Given the well documented negative impacts of bullying on people of all ages, I cannot in good conscience recommend 'Bully: Scholarship Edition'.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												I played Bully so much on my PS2 when I was young and never had the chance to finish it and get the 100%, and I did all this on the Steam version. It's surely my favorite Rockstar game.-The story is very good, not too complex or outstanding, but it's very good.-The map is not too large, it's even kinda small if compared to other Rockstar titles, but you have anough stuff to do in it, so that's not such a big problem.-The missions are fun, really, really fun.-Side missions are as much fun and entertaining.-Lots of secrets to unlock.-It's addictive and fun to play the whole game, but sometimes it can get a bit repetitive, so you need to take a break when that happens, and come back after some time.-There are bugs, but they never really interfered in my experience, except the people walking around and their sounds being heard from the other side of the map.Also, if you have that bug when you start the game and everything disappear, you can fix this with a patch (just Google search "bully bug fix" and you'll probably find it somewhere).

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Pros: Good conceptCons: Everything else, specifically the game content and the apalling interfaceThis is a very poor quality port. I haven't played it on a console, but it's obvious that it's not a PC game. To start with, the mouse control is atrociously bad. I can't see where I'm going and I needed to get a trackpad just to pick locks. The menu interfaces are diabolical: you have to use left shift control and space to select things that a mouse could click just as easily. The fight controls are similarly awful and hard to get the hang of. A mouse click would do the same job as holding r and left shift. Sprinting is a waste of effort too. Who wants to quickly tap shift?On to the game itself. The "missions" I've completed so far are so interesting that I want to stick my head in an oven. I had to speak to the headmaster, get some chocolates for a butch neurotic lesbian and walk to two classes. Oh, and then I had to put someone in a bin after chasing them for a few minutes. It's so unengaging I'd rather organise my desktop icons.For a game released in 2008, I can't help thinking that the graphics are a bit substandard too, but that's not really important. The glitchy sound is also very annoying. Oh, and I have to walk to some irrelevant room just to save. That would have been alright if this game was fun like Vice City, but it wasn't fun at all. The walks to the save room just gave me time to contemplate how♥♥♥♥♥♥it was.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												One of the unsung gems of Rockstar, Bully can be aptly described as "GTA for kids," but yet so much more. Don't let that tagline fool you, Bully is nearly as good as, if not better, than its M-Rated cousin, and deserves the cult following. Its missions are high in number but short and sweet, and it's easy to wreak havoc in the schoolyards witout a shred of guilt. More importanty, Jimmy Hopkins is a genuinely likeable character, which is saying a lot considering he's the poster boy for an angsty teenager. One of the better protagonists crafted by Rockstar by far, and simultaneously allow players to cause chaos at Bullworth without the cognitive dissonance and easily slip back into the role of a hero when the story calls for it.It would be wise, however, to skip out on the PC version, which is a lousy port, and go straight for the console versions, either for the Wii or the 360's HD edition.But if you want a short-but-sweet "Steam style" review, here's one!I said "hi" to a nerd. He tried to punch me in return. A prefect came and kicked his♥♥♥♥♥for me. 10/10.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												This is a great blast from the past. Have you ever been bullied. Yes:well this is your chance to fight back! No, I bullied people: Well great uoull fit right in.Pros: Give wedgies, throw people in lockers, skip class, start fights, run from the cops, ride a ferris wheel, destroy gnomes for a carnie, and throwsnowballs at cars, this games great. It has the factions that dominate the schoolgrounds(before the emo/hipster/swag phase) such as the Jocks, Nerds, Bullies, Outcasts, and Greasers(yeah Greasers, bring the spud cannon). You dont have the largest aresnal in a game, but your in school, start off with a slingshot, get a skateboard, build your bicycle, make friends(advance in story) to get more weapons. Some weapons can be learned in class such as the stink bombs and firework launcher.Cons: The games dated, but not terribly. Think of going back to GTA:SA with a Vice city sized map( I guess), no lethal guns, only forms of are your always handy skatebord, and bicycles,no strippers.If you like what Rockstar puts out, but want less "adult content" then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												It's definitely a fun game. Get to live the moments I missed in my own time in high school, like kissing all the girls XDThere's a vast array of missions you can do as well as running errands for some quick cash. It's a great open world game. Story so far seems pretty good too. I have had a few issues with the game however. There are some random lags I get as well as the mouse not working too well. Which can be annoying depending on the mission (ie aiming in first person, sometimes the mouse will jump past the target making me have to restart) as well as having experienced a never ending loop of the load screen and characters freezing during animations, forcing a game restart. The last 2 examples have only happened to me once each, so it seems to be a rare event, but thought I should mention it.With that said, if you save often, it's not a game breaking problem and I've really enjoyed this game.

content:
Posted: March 25
												This game worked okay for me on Windows 10 if I ran in compatibility mode (XP Service Pack 3) and as administrator, without display scaling. (Otherwise the display didn't fit my screen even with the correct resolution.) But using a keyboard and mouse, the controls make it really difficult to play. I couldn't get past the lockpicking tutorial because moving the mouse didn't really move the lock (it would randomly go in either direction no matter what I did). Since I'm stuck there at the beginning, I won't be playing farther. It sounds like a great game from other reviews so I'm pretty disappointed in the port.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Having gotten this game back in Christmas 2007, I was young (10) and I fell in the love with the game. I loved the music, the humour, the characters, the brilliant attention to detail and most of all... the replay value. I have re-played and completed this game over Twenty-Seven times! Twenty--Seven... when have you ever loved a game sooooo much you played it Twenty-Seven times to the end? The fact is this is the perfect game. Perfect setting, perfect characters and an insane amount of fun! This game will never leave my mind, and I'm STILL waiting for a sequel. RockStar surprise us. Bring us Bully 2 and make it good. It will be hard to recapture the beatuy that is Canis Canem Edit, but if anyone can do it.. its RockStar.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Pros:- Pretty much a soft-core version of GTA.- A lot of NPC's, each with different ( and funny ) dialogue.- Made by Rockstar.- Six different cliques, all unique, including Nerds, Jocks, Preppies, Bullies, Greasers, and Townies.- You can attend classes ( which are pretty fun minigames which you can unlock extra items from )- Instead of guns, you get makeshift weapons like fire-crackers, stink bombs, a slingshot, and even rotten eggs.- You can beat up old ladies.- Completely non-linear.- You can save people from the bullies, or even bully them yourself.- Instead of stealing cars, you can steal bikes, and scooters.Cons: - For a game made in 2008, the graphics don't seem that up-to-dateRating: 10/10Don't think, just buy this game! c:

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												GAME DOES NOT WORK.Absolutely appalling. I always wanted to play Bully. Too bad the game crashes while loading. Spent hours trying everything anyone has ever said to do. No dice. Windows XP emulation? Nope. Patches? Nope. Registry? Nope. Drivers? Nope. CPU affinity to 1? Nope.Windows 7 (NOT 10), 64-bit and still "too new" to run? Please.As a software developer, I have to say this is one of the crappiest ports I have ever seen. I can still run Thief 1: The Dark Project. I can run Trespassor and Outcast. Duke Nukem 3D still runs. But apparently a game Rockstar is still selling is too much to ask for to run on a system that came out in 2009. (Bully came out for PC in 2008.)Moral of the story? Even though Steam allows refunds now. You damn well better test the game before that period runs out. You can't simply "trust" Rockstar as a brand and come back after a few weeks and play your game. There are apparently hundreds of people burned by this if you search online... buyer beware, indeed.It's 2015 and Rockstar is still selling this game. There is no excuse for a AAA-company not running quality assurance. But that's the key... isn't it? An indie company can't afford to screw over people and still make money. If I wrote software that broke like this, I'd be out of a job.If you guys fix your game, I'll gladly edit this review.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2015
Bully: Scholarship Edition is a beat'em up adventure game. New kid Jimmy Hopkins must make his place among the bullies, nerds and jocks of Bullworth Academy, making allies and enemies while pulling pranks and getting into fights.Pros: The game is large enough, beginning with the Academy, but opening more of the town as you play. There's plenty of missions to go through and characters to interact with. Pulls a lot of humor and setting from 1990s kids TV show stereotypes.Cons: This game is a bad PC port that plays awfully without a game pad. The graphics lost all their charms with age. The story isn't involving, having none of the sarcastic flair other Rockstar games such as the Grand Theft Auto franchise has, so there is little to no reason to revisit it once you've played through it.Verdict: ★★☆☆☆ - Forget itI take my nostalgia goggles off and look at it from a fresh perspective, and find little interest. I scratch my head wondering why I found it appealing some years ago, but will not be going back to Bully: Scholarship Edition again.—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

												An ancient game with some fresh ideas on adventure genre.Somewhat silly (kiss someone to get more HP), it's fun actually. Should I say, was fun?1. The game is crashing more than Fallout3 on it's release and you can't stop that by any means, with point #1 this makes you a masochist4. Rockstar doesn't care for PC and from consoles they switched to phones now.Do not make the same mistake I did. Do not buy this broken piece of s. There are better games from developers that care about PC.I couldn't bring myself to finish this, repeating something endlessly just because the game crashes like crazy is a slap to the face of any proper gamer.Uninstall.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												It's a fun open world game made by RockStar but clearly shows it's age in terms of gameplay. Basically your main character, James 'Jimmy' Hopkins, is your standard errand boy. Go here, do what someone told him to do, rinse and repeat. It's an okay gameplay mechanic back then but is dated by today's standards. One thing I really dislike about this game is the rewards for completing missions, which is money. Normally it's fine to get money as a reward but in this game, there's almost nothing you can or want to buy. Money is useless.All in all, for a 10 hour game, this is a must buy for open world fans. If it's too expensive, then wait for a sale. I got mine at about $9.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												Good game for console, but♥♥♥♥♥♥PC port.Pros: 1. Pretty good story.2. Decent fighting.3. Good character development.4. Many "adult" jokes.5. Quite a bit of things to do.6. Classes are quite fun sometimes.aaaaannnddd thats where the Pros end.Cons:1. TERRIBLE PC port.2. Game crashes every 2-10 minutes.3. Nothing i've tried fixes these crashes.4. Game is unplayable with these crashes.5. Game caps at 30 fps unless you download another exe which im not sure is reliable or not.6. Games story becomes mundane after a while as many missions are the same, (example is missions where you literally beat people up)7. Repetitive boss fight concepts.8. Boss fights are WAY TOO EASY.9. Overpriced for a game that's barely functionable and is this old.10. Buggy AI that sometimes glitch and bug out, causing you to have to restart some missions.11. The game really makes you hate almost all the social classes in the game, atleast in my experience.Overall, I don't recommend buying this game at full price, but I instead recommend people who want to give it a try to wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												An enjoyable and great take on the GTA open world concept with a much less menacing and zero bloody content. I'd recommend it but with reservations.*minor spoiler*The game sees the protaganist rise his way up the school hierachy. Throughout the story, the game will involve performing acts of violence, coercion, pranks, harassment, vandalism, voyeurism, defying authority (with or without good reason), and other questionable acts to reach the goal of getting to the top of the school hierachy. Though most of  the acts ingame are justified as befitting of the crapsack world setting, I'm not so sure students who are in a maturing phase should be stimulated with such content.I played this game on the PS2 when I was 17, it was mostly a silly game to me back then, but now as an adult; having revisted this game recently, I'd definitely have reservations for letting 13 year old students play this.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Parents need to know that this game is an expansion of the original 2006 Bully game offered on newer platforms, and that it depicts antisocial behavior and violence within a school environment. At its heart it is a simulation about bullying behavior in a school setting and therefore -- given the sad state of school violence -- a hot-button topic for parents. There is plenty of psychological mischief and physical violence, including fistfighting, kicking, humiliating taunts and insults. Weapons include a slingshot, firecracker launcher, baseball bat, garbage can lid, and fire extinguisher, but there are no guns or bombs, nor is there any gore, serious injuries, or deaths. The Wii edition makes use of the console's motion sensitive controls to punch, but doesn't make players engage in the physical act of punching. The game contains some sexual remarks, sexual pranks (stealing girls' underwear and sneaking into a bathroom to try to get a photo of a girl in the shower (all you see is steam), and alcohol references. And depending on the path taken, the main character, Jimmy Hopkins, can kiss another boy. Pranks include pushing kids into toilets, tossing stinkbombs, firecrackers, and itching powder at pedestrians, and throwing marbles on the ground for others to trip over. The game does include consequences for misdeeds. The game performed better than expected on PC. I played on the original version on PS2. I higly reccomend playing this game; however, I would highly reccommend playing with a controller! 5 out of 5 Stars

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												I've had hundreds of hours of this game on my old playstation, so don't be decieved by my game time.I have always loved this game and for many reasons. One of my favorite things to do was stuff people in lockers or hit children and girls just to get into BIG trouble. I loved the storyline and the ending was great. I think that the only thing wrong with this game is that there will probably never be a sequel, which shatters my heart. If you hate highschool, you will love this game. If you love highschool, you will love this game. If you never went to highschool for some reason, you will love this game. The game's so old, yet it runs beatifully on my modern computer. I reccomend this game to anyone looking for a story rich, free roam, high school simulator, nostalgic (even if you haven't played the game before), butt kicking time. If you haven't bought this game WAAAAY back then, and you were a gamer WAAAAAY back then, then i'm honestally dissapointed in you for existing.TL;DR?10/10, A masterpiece- no, a symbol for classics everywhere, or one might say that it's "the game that describes what a classic game is", or as Jimmy Hopkins would say, "Fun for the whole family, OF ME!"

number of helpful: 8 of 21 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												$2.99?! Awesome deal and bought it! Here's what I think:Keep in mind... I love Rockstar games. Bully has a nice gameplay, world design, and great voice actors. I don't even have an hour into the game and already I'm getting frustrated playing it. First off... the controls. I don't feel comfortable with how the key bindings are. Change them? I tried and that changes a lot more than it says. One key binding has like 3 uses for it and doesn't even mention them. I've tried DS3 but unfortunately, it wasn't connecting. Secondly... the frames aren't that great. If you're really expecting good frames from this game, then lower your expectations. I'd say 30 fps MAX. I get framerate from a beginning cutscene. Third... 40 minutes into the game and it crashes. Once I found out that there's no autosave, I gave up, flipped the table, and wrote this. If you REALLY want a game with better frames that is open-world as well, spend just a little bit more on other games. I honestly don't recommend this game BUT if you really want to try out Bully... be my guest, since it is $2.99 for now.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Side note: I owned the PS2 version and the Xbox 360 Version, 100% both of them.Bully is one of R*'s crowning achievements. Memorable characters, locations and missions. I can say with great certainty that it is one of my favorite games of R*'s. If I could I would recommend this game a thousand times over.Now, for the sad part and why I can't recommend it to you. The PC version is a mess. Running on my 760, the game flashes black screens and stutters. Running on my i5's intergrated graphics, it's flawless. The keyboard support is a mess but I have X360 controllers on hand so that doesn't bother me but for those without that could be a deal breaker.So, You've been warned. One of R*'s greatest games is a horrible mess on PC. Do you have an older laptop that might be bad enough to run the game? Buy it in a heartbeat. If you have anything halfway decent, I'd be worried.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												I'm sorry to have to give this game a negative review because there a lots of positive things about it and only a small number of negative.  But one negative is a game breaker.    Bully is set in a residential school where your character is dumped by his mother and his new stepfather at the start of term.  For all the furore of the game's title the game is part of a mileu of childhood fiction - aspects of the "Just William" stories, "Tom Brown's Schooldays", "Dennis and Gnasher" "The Bash Street Kids" and "Mean Girls".    Although violence is epidemic and endemic in the school - GBH with baseball bats being regarded as "character forming" by the headmaster there's no need for your character to be a sadistic bully.  Indeed the game system, particularly at the start, favours running away from most fights and most of the missions involve helping people and pranks rather than outright sadism.    The school day breaks down into lessons (two a day) and free time where you can do various missions and favours.  Getting to class is always stressful because the game never tells you where your class is until it starts involving a mad dash to avoid hall monitors and staff to avoid truanting.  The classes themselves are mini games ranging from the very simple (music just requiring you to hit left or right trigger in reponse to the screen), to tricky (the word puzzles in English need pretty high skills), to very tricky (Biology needs you to be fast and accurate with your controls), to extremely difficult (the workshop's control tests are murderously difficult).  By the way DON'T get the game if you haven't got an X-Box for PC controller.  If you don't pass a class you keep on retaking it.   The outside class missions involve object finding, fighting, stealth and obstacle navigation.  Often you will find yourself having to run away from bullies and staff.  A skateboard may seem the better option to get away but the game has a nasty habit of flicking your perspective near objects like walls leaving you confused and trapped.  Inventory controls are clumsy with rearranging your inventory being difficult and no way to store the equipment (stink bombs, marbles, a catapult etc.) off yourperson.  Also the game bizarrely sees to lack a "Start from beginning" option so there's no way to erase a bad day without going to a previous save.   Your character sleeps but doesn't eat (a relief after the first canteen mission).    Overall the game is good fun.  The school characters and charicatures are well drawn with the language making the game unsuitable for younger, more impressionable gamers.  Also once you enter the second chaper the game world expands dramatically.  The game bumbles along whether you succeed in class or fail, succeed in missions or fail.    You can buy new items and clothing but other than mission specific items there's no indication whether these items affect gameplay at all.    Why the negative review then ?   The game crashes.  Rockstar has been aware or ought to have been aware of the problem for at least a year but the game still crashes.  There's no autosave function so since time is always ticking and is a significant limitation in the game you don't ten to go back to your bedroom (where the save ledger is) until the end of each day.  So if the game crashes late in an evening you could find yourself having to repeat two lessons and two missions you'd already completed.  On average having adjusted my setting I get about 90 minutes of play between crashes - which can then involve losing an hour of gameplay.   This would have been a strongly (but not overwhemingly) positive review without this flaw but with it the game is so annoying as to actively put you off playing.  Which is a shame because Bully is probably a better game than the first three GTAs at least.S.x.

number of helpful: 12 of 31 people (39%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												A butchered port of the Console version, This is one of the few rare examples of a console game being better on the console than the PC. The keyboard and mouse controls are cumbersome to say the least, if i didn't have to slide my mouse across my mouse pad several times to inch the camera up to aim at something i was asked to shoot or take a picture of I'd be fine but this only begins my many gripes about this port of the game. The graphics have this weird glow about them, no matter how low you bring down the brightness its still there along with this awkward foggyness that looks like a cheap cover up for draw distance on a ps1. Along with the fact that the textures sometimes flicker and shake awkwardly. Randomly cutscenes will not play after key moments in the game are complete, The controls make many of the missions much more difficult to complete than they would if I just used a controller, Seriously use a 360 controller if you're going to play this game properly, or just buy the 360 version. I feel as though rockstar had no time to put forth the effort to make this game work for PC's in the first place. The graphics look incredibly dated even more so to the fact that this is basically an HD remake of the ps2 version. I really love the console version of this game and have sunken many hours into it on the 360, I can happily say I'm glad i only purchased this version for about 5 dollars on a sale because the frustrating controls and poor graphics make it not worth more than a few dollars. This game by it self is so excellent it tells a great and interesting story with alot of great jokes that come along with it but it being on a PC ruins it completely. The Options feature standard console graphical options and that is all, no chance at turning down this weird glow effect the game has. This version of the game is not worth buying get the console version if you actually want to enjoy it.

number of helpful: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												“Bully: Scholarship Edition” takes a refreshing turn in the modern shooting and killing genre, by having a quirky and childish game that takes place in a UK boarding school. The game begins with his mother and his step-dad dropping the protagonist (Jimmy) off at one of the toughest boarding schools in the nation. They proceed to laugh at Jimmy as they voice their plan to go have fun off at their honeymoon. Ironically, this is an accurate allusion to Jimmy’s future because there is very little fun to be had in the school and consequently this game. In a game where it simply falls in both humor and gameplay, there are very few positive things that I can say about “Bully: Scholarship Edition” other than the fact that it is a bit innovative. I want to begin first by dissuading the illusion that this game is for children. With the amount of sexual implications, cultural references, drug use, and so on, the audience is likely to be people who have had the experience or are undergoing the experience of secondary schooling (high school). I wanted to establish this early on so that when I talk about things that are a little bit more complex, the idea that this game is for children is no longer an argument. The gameplay is refreshingly lacking of guns, but has a strong centralization on hand-to-hand combat. I found it funny that the lessons learned in classes translated into violence used on campus. Unfortunately the player is discouraged from using violence, as you will get caught by the prefects and punished. It is simply easier to just let anyone bothering you get caught by prefects rather than acting in self-defense. Outside combat, the diverse gameplay is very tedious. The classes are all very basic mini-games (most of them QTE) that, if done successfully, gives some sort of reward. Talking about rewards there are three kinds, money, clothing, skill-ups. While skill-ups are small benefits for your character, money and clothing are nearly worthless. A large portion of money goes into aesthetics and clothing is nearly entirely aesthetics, but having different clothing than your uniform gets you in trouble by the prefects which nulls their usability. This is confusing because Jimmy likes money; he will do anything for money but the game fails to acknowledge its purpose. Furthermore  SPOILER ALERT  at the end of chapter one, Jimmy says to the leader of the bullies (Russel) that the bullies should stop bullying the weak (nerds) but rather to fight those who deserve it. Russel acknowledges this, but there is no change on campus, bullies are still bullying the nerds. The players see no change or benefit due to their actions, making the entire ordeal and arc meaningless. Furthermore, the plot becomes meaningless as "Jimmy's rise to power" when he voices that he doesn't want power. SPOILERS END The gameplay while diverse, is simply monotonous. Most of the gameplay is not a challenge, and are lengthy in duration: a bad combination. For example, to get accepted into the nerd base, you need to beat their score at a 2d plane scroller, similar to snake. The mini game was simple, you play as a sumo that collects food and avoids hazards and everything moves linearly. As you collect the food, you get more points, but it doesn’t increase in difficulty or challenge. The sumo doesn’t get bigger or slower, nor does the game spawn more hazards; you just play repetitively until you want to. This example is similar to a lot of the gameplay in “Bully: Scholarship Edition”, a test of endurance for the monotonous and repetitiveness.      The game features an extreme stereotype of each of the cliques in secondary schooling, with nerds, jocks, prefects and so on. However the humor of each of the clique falls flat when the extremism is never moderated. The humor is not subtle, all the characters are just screaming with obnoxious stereotypes that just become jumbled and contrasted but never emphasized. Furthermore the dialogue lines are not diverse, meaning that you will hear the same lines over and over. For example, I was running the same way as a prefect character who muttered “I want a hotdog” over and over. This isn’t humor, this is abhorrent. The players simply cannot engage with the characters or plot if they are all simply flat stereotypes. Finally, the worst thing about this game is the audio. Like I stated earlier, it is very irksome to hear the same lines being repeated over and over. However, on top of that there seems to be no depth of hearing. There is the same volume for a speaker talking next to me as there is for a fight going on half the campus away. Thus imagine walking around campus, and hearing a cacophony of dialogue, each difficult to distinguish, on top of the other in-game sounds. One cut scene was next to the ocean, and the ocean sounds washed over all the dialogue that happened in that scene. The next bit was a bike race in where there was a disembodied voice that shouted “EXTREME” over and over until the race ended. With all these in mind, and I pray my mind is still sane, I cannot recommend this game.

number of helpful: 11 of 29 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
												Imagine you took all the Americana Juvinalia films (the Sandlot, Meatballs, Revenge of the Nerds, Porky's, A Christmas Story, etc), blended them into a fine paste and made a video game from it. That would be what Bully is.I wish I could recommend it. I wish I could say its better because it's unique and can be a lot of fun, but it does get a bit stale by the middle of the game.Gameplay wise, the missions are what you would guess. You egg houses, raid panties, french girls and all the stuff you'd expect from something of this genre. You learn different melee moves and you get ranged weapons, both of which are useful in many cases. There is a bit of variety in missions, but some of the missions are the same as in previous chapters, just with a difference of location and enemy.Also, something really, really annoying: Sometimes if you fail a mission you will not get the chance to do it until the next day. I know the game has to punish you for failing, but I would have preferred to just restart the mission.The story kind of wore on me after a while. I didn't really get attached to any of the characters because they wheeled them around like I was riding a rollercoaster past everyone in the school. I wasn't too thrilled that I had to go through all the factions pretty much doing the same types of missions in order to boost my reputation with them. There was a bit of predictability. I didn't really laugh as much as I would have expected from a comedy game. Though, the ending did get me super psyched and that made up for a lot of confusion during the middle of the game. It feels like you lose the purpose of the game near the middle.The open world seems small at first glance, but it is designed excellently. There's a lot of nooks and crannies to get lost in. There's a few collectibles, but not the obscene amount that you see in most open world games.The music is quite unique as well. The soundtrack is usually dominated by bass guitar with xylophone paired with celeste, which gives it a feel all its own. The problem is that some of the tracks aren't looped well and you'll be listening to 10 second clips stop then start again. Also, in regards to the sound design, some of the dialogue, which is excellent, is drowned out by the sound effects and you'll frequently find yourself straining to listen.I did run into one bug that caused the game to get stuck in a cutscene. I had to reload from an earlier point and that sucked.I really want to recommend this game, but it has its share of problems. If you're looking for something different this isn't a terrible choice, but bear in mind that this game has a LOT of annoying issues.

												I will admit that I came to the party pretty late with this one. This game is using a modified version of the game engine that powered GTA: San Andreas but that's a good thing. However, the game is now starting to show its age, even with the updated visuals. It's a shame that I didn't play this before GTA V as the age of the game is very apparent if you play this after GTA V. But.....it IS still a good game, not as good as it would have been a few years ago but still worth your time. The main story is rather short considering that it was made by Rockstar, but with all the side missions chucked in you're looking to a good 20-30 hours of gameplay. I would recommend this game to anyone that likes GTA or anyone that likes the idea of being the toughest SOB in the whole school! 8/10.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												I spent a fair amount of time playing this game before I made a decision on whether or not I liked this game. Unfortunately I don't like.I always had an interest in this game all the way back when it was first announced years ago but never picked it up. Until recently.What good things can I say about this game. It has the usual Rockstar Style. Open world, tons of missions and a good variety, collectibles, side missions, tons of them. This game also allowed me to do things that I haven't been able to do in my own life. Such as have friends throughout my school life and go on dates with girls. There is also a fairground where you can win tickets and exchange them for prizes. The game is full of content, the game is also well written as you'd expect from a Rockstar game.Unfortunately all of that content doesn't really mean anything if the rest of the game is terrible. When I started playing this game and I looked at all the textures and models I honestly thought that this game was made shortly after GTA3 however it turns out that it was made after GTA:SA. Whilst the textures and models have never really looked great in Rockstar's games I did expect better. Another issue with this game is the absolutely nightmarish controls, such as alt to run, shift to punch and tab to view the map, the combination of these buttons often resulted in me minimizing the game accidentally.There is a reputation system in this game that allows you to pick who your friends and enemies are, however the story missions make you hop from one group of people to the next essentially infuriating them all by the end.This pretty much makes the rep system null and void. The prefects which have taken the role as the police in this game as they seem to have power not just in the school but in the nearby town as well, apparently the prefects own the entire town 'Tommy Vercetti' style.I didn't find the game all that interesting but it seemed to last far too long for me.If you like Rockstar you might be able to put up with this game but I couldn't.

												They should have called this Bully: Broken Port Edition.My journey to get Bully: Broken Port Edition to run was an a very frustrating one. When I saw that the splash loading screen before the intro video was going nowhere fast, I did the usual when problems like this arise; Set compatibility mode to windows XP, checked "Run this program as Administrator", and tried to start it again. Same splash screen lock up. Disabled desktop composition, and was excited when the intro videos now played; but then nearly swore frustratedly at my PC monitor once it then promptly crashed not half a second after the logo videos finished. I then googled a solution; hoping that I would find some user made fix, and it brought me to this thread http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=786851 which was of no help in the slightest as I already did everything suggested. I then looked to the steam community hub, and anyone who has had similar issues was met with replies along the lines of "Must be something wrong with your PC, works great on mine! I guess you're♥♥♥♥♥♥out of luck." Well, that's fantastic that you got this game to work on your PC, but my game is still ♥♥♥♥ing broken, so you're not helping. There are also rumors of game breaking bugs and a 30fps cap in the PC port from those who have miraculously somehow been able to get past the first loading screen, so it probably wasn't worth the trouble anyway.If you really want to play Bully, do it by other means. content:
Posted: March 18, 2012
												Not nearly as good as I thought it would be. It looked like "Grand Theft Auto at a boarding school." And that's more or less what it is. I played it for a couple hours, and it just never grabbed me. The idea is really cool, and the story's not bad. The gameplay is solid, and it's fun. I dunno. I just never latched on.The problem is I expected it to be a little less GTA and a little more Harry Potter. In reality, it essentially is GTA without cars. I was hoping RockStar would do something a little different, but they really didn't. I'm pretty sure they actually used the GTA engine to build this game.Which is fine; it just doesn't really make the game very compelling, what with the swarm of GTA games that I'd been playing back when I picked this up. And now that style of game is becoming as ubiquitous as Diablo clones. Saints Row now has a third sequel, and is pretty much no different than GTA.At any rate. Bully is not a bad game, it's just too much like Grand Theft Auto to be interesting if you've already play Grand Theft Auto.

number of helpful: 1 of 13 people (8%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												If you're not interested in a game that presents sexist, racist, and weightist views, you should avoid this game. 25 minutes into the game it is already quite clear that it is full of nothing but harmful stereotypes, no doubt another example of Rockstar's famous “satire.” Whatever the intention of these depictions, they are still presenting negative views of people. I'm writing this for the socially conscious gamer who does not find it fun to be immersed in a world populated by the most vulgar and hateful stereotypes humanity has to offer. If you can find enjoyment in this game, good for you. It doesn't matter to me if people like this game or not, and I'm not trying to attack or put down people who do. I'm only interested in saving people the money and time if this is not the kind of game they would be interested in.Here's a breakdown of what the first 25 minutes have to offer:Sexism: every female character encountered was an extreme stereotype that presented a very negative view of women and their sexuality. It really came across as misogynistic. Weightism: The dialogue of fat NPCs while walking around the world was designed to make them appear unintelligent and reflected common harmful stereotypes. The first fat character the PC interacts with, a girl at the school, is given a deep, unfeminine voice and is crying because her chocolate was stolen.Racism: the only two black characters the PC interacted with were presented as enemies. This was just in the first 25 minutes, but it was not a promising start. Vulgarity: a minor annoyance, but definitely something be aware of: the NPCs walking around the world constantly shout out immature insults.I couldn't play longer than 25 minutes because I found the content too distasteful, however I can't imagine the game gets much better. The entire thing just had a very hateful and immature feel to it. I hope this was helpful, I know I would have liked to see a review covering these issues before I bought the game. On another note, If it wasn't for its socially regressive content it looked like it would have been a fun game, so if you can get past that you might like it.

number of helpful: 3 of 20 people (15%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Cringey from beginning to end. The school, the 'manipulations', the pranks, the alpha-male boneheaded decisions, the prepubescent writing, the inconsistencies of characters, the unrelatability and lack of empathy for the protagonist... There's really nothing to like here. I was going to play this game as a kid on PS2, but never got to it, and finally did on PC, and I wish I had never heard of it. Rockstar would have been better off making a childish game about prison, because at least they could get more into the issues of sex, violence, and guns. The overall plot is poorly stitched together and makes no sense. Characters go from being livid over betrayal to gullibly innocent or humbly reclusive to recklessly ambitious in the same cutscene.This game in a nutshell: be a king of school by beating up everyone in the way (because that's all it'll ever take) and tonguekissing literally any and every girl available to you. I'm astonished you aren't shanked or shot by the end of the game.If you want to know about port issues: 1. There are no camera control options. And it sucks. You'll have the camera flip between 180 changes midfight causing you to miss all the time. 2. You can't access even audio options until you start the game and watch through the first cutscene. 3. All other options are super barebones. 4. 6 save slots. Because you know, memory card limitations. 5. It does crash, just rarely. But save often.

number of helpful: 10 of 35 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												This is an old bug riddled game, its not worth picking up, I've wasted my money on this trash.From crappy keybinds to game breaking bugs, I really recommend avoiding this title because well, I doubt Rockstar is going to update a game thats 5 years old now. When I talk about bugs, i'm talking about the combat system, its litterally horrible, it seems Jimmy can't pick up weapons without instantly dropping them, making it impossible to complete one of the missions where you have to pick up bricks and throw them at a thug that you happen to be chasing for sling shotting you.And of course, the keybinds, who on earth throught that shift was a good key for attacking and alt was perfect for sprinting? I mean seriously, its always been traditional with games for shift to be for sprinting and mouse buttons for attacking.Ontop of that is class room activities requiring you to have super accurate timing right down to the split second while padlock picking forces you to rotate your mouse in a way that just feels so uncomfortable its asking to give you a Repetitive strain injury.

number of helpful: 5 of 25 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												It's basically GTA as a grade schooler.  Missions open up as you complete more, but many are restricted to a certain time of the day.  That plus the slower modes of travel make the pacing a lot slower than other rockstar games and can feel like it's being dragged out.    The gameplay isn't very exciting, missions are short do one little thing then come back, and the customization/upgrading doesn't do much to enhance the experience.  The story is about a douchey little kid, fighting with other douchey little kids for control of a school ran by douchey people in a town full of douchey people which I found completely offputting.  The music, random npc dialogue, and cutscenes (if the game bugs out on you and you have to redo missions) get old quick.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												It's clear that Bully: Scholarship Edition is not my favorite game, but at the same time, I feel like you are missing out on a good experience if you have not played this game. The Scholarship Edition has added missions, NPCs, classes, and items to the game, however, in my opinion, they are not worth re-buying the game if you have already completed the older version on the Ps2. The graphics may not be the prettiest you’ve ever seen, and the controls surely aren’t going to be your favorite, but the pure amount of detail and time that went into this game shouldn’t be ignored or looked past. Upon release, this game was already at a disadvantage due to being released on the Ps2 after the newer generation had already started, and Xbox 360 games were on the rise. All that being said, I must admit, I do look forward to the hinted(1) sequel(2). Read my full official review here: http://nerdbacon.com/bully-scholarship-edition-pc/

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 17, 2013
												Bully is a game such as the GTA series. Only this time you play as a kid that has just started at a boarding school. Since it's in the gta universe, you know it's going to messed up, in a good way. The game mechanics work as GTA does. You can go to a bunch of different locations to trigger missions, you can run around and pick up weapons and items, attack anyone you see, and use some vehicles. Since you're a kid, you can't take any cars, but there are bikes, skate boards, and the likes of which. The main story has a good flow, and is exciting, and only actually counts for 50% of the game, yet it taking a good amount of time to finish. The game I think is set in the 70s and has a great soundtrack made to fit. All in all, it's a classic Rockstar game. Being one of the older games that came out on PS2 first, it has a little worse graphics than the norm, but if you give it a chance and play it for a while, you'll get used it.

content:

												This game is an underrated (HEAVILY UNDERRATED) classic. It's probably one of the few titles that we'll ever see that tickles on the prospect of innocence (or lack thereof) of the American teenage youth. Or any teenage youth for that matter!A charming, comical story with laugh out loud cliche stereotypes (you have your jocks, your geeks, your preppies, etc.,) and a sense of reminesce that at some point in time, we were somebody at this school.Though the game is quite dated, again, I call it a classic because it's one of the few games I'd actually go back and play again (I originally played the hell out of this on the XBOX360!)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2013
												I bought this a couple weeks back for the full price in order to relive the experience that I remember on my PS2. Not only is it the same great game, but it's been reworked on an entirely new and improved game engine, along with added classes and extra missions. Nostalgia with added gameplay features. In my personal opinion, The world of Bully is the most interactive and immerseful world Rockstar has created yet, so much so that I can almost consider it a simulation. Bully makes you feel like a student at Bullworth, and gives you the freedom to do whatever you will in this universe. If Bully is a title you have missed, or even if you have played the Canis Canem Edit a few years back, Bully: Scholarship Edition is a highly polished Rockstar title that is absolutely not to be passed up, especially if you're reading this and it's still -75% off.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												A game misunderstood as trying to sell violence to children. This game is about trying to fight violence among children -- first by fighting the bullies, then by fighting the rich jerks, and then by fighting the abusive jocks. The title can actually be thought of as ironic -- it has little or nothing to do with "being" a bully and everything to do with what you will do against other bullies.That all said in its defence, it's still a "grand theft bicycle" game if you ever want to get onto the wild side a little. But if anyone sees that as being the forest, they're really missing the trees.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2013
												I bought this a couple weeks back for the full price in order to relive the experience that I remember on my PS2. Not only is it the same great game, but it's been reworked on an entirely new and improved game engine, along with added classes and extra missions. Nostalgia with added gameplay features. In my personal opinion, The world of Bully is the most interactive and immerseful world Rockstar has created yet, so much so that I can almost consider it a simulation. Bully makes you feel like a student at Bullworth, and gives you the freedom to do whatever you will in this universe. If Bully is a title you have missed, or even if you have played the Canis Canem Edit a few years back, Bully: Scholarship Edition is a highly polished Rockstar title that is absolutely not to be passed up, especially if you're reading this and it's still -75% off.
