number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												A shining example of Rockstar's ability to tackle, what seem like at the time, impossibly politcally incorrect subjects.  This game was originally released in 2006 on the PS2, and during that time was one of the games that shaped me as a person. Bully follows the life of Jimmy Hopkins, a by no means perfect teen, through his life at Bullworth Academy. He comes from broken home, with a mother who by no means cares for him, and a multitude of stepfathers. When Jimmy is introduced into the school he quickly learns that those who cannot physically stand up for themselves are tormented relentlessly, and that it is not only tolerated, but encouraged by the school. Jimmy is by no means a bully himself, but tries to establish himself as a sort of bringer of justice in the school, by systematically humilating the kids who needlessly bully others. This game was far ahead of it's time, it expertly tackled subjects that no other developer would dare undertake at the time, and in my opinion withstands the 8 years of aging. While the story is a very interesting social commentary on things like broken homes, and bullying, as the name implies, it's gameplay did not withstand the test of time in the same way it's story did. The game is essentially unplayable without a controller, is a godawful port in almost every way, and has very simplistic fighting mechanics. The game is capped at 30FPS, and when uncapped will break certain missions. The fighting essentially entails kick, block, punch, and while the additions of things like the slingshot or marbles can make it slightly more enjoyable, it's still pretty repitive. Overall I'd say it's worth it for the story and, as any good Rockstar game contains, great social commentary alone. Although if you're very gameplay centered I'd say wait for a sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												I've wanted to play this game a while, but the performance, presentation and general graphical quality of this port leave much to be desired. My eyes physically hurt from looking at the (lack of) antialiasing, and there is no option to turn the graphics quality up - in fact, there are no graphics options beyond "brightness" and "subtitles". I normally don't get hung up on the graphical quality of games, but this... this looks and feels as if I'm playing a PC game from about thirteen or fourteen years ago, right down to the Star Wars: Dark Forces style blocky washed-out menus. That would be kind of acceptable on its own, but the game also runs terribly, chugging along at a paltry rate, and the controls are godawful. I think I might just get this on X-box, where it belongs.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 12, 2012
												Despite Bully being originally a PS2 game and therefore it being riddled with glitches this is a really awesome Sandbox game. Basically it's GTA in a school setting and of course the crimes are a lot less severe. This game is tons of fun, the characters are lively and colourful and the stereotypical groups (Nerds, Preps, Greasers, Jocks, Townies, Prefects) are well defined as the main story has you, Jimmy Hopkins, deal with these groups and has you climb to the top of the school to eventually face your nemesis Gary Smith, a sociopathic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who causes trouble behind the scenes. The main story gives you a good variety of missions to do and you can also interact with others in a variety of ways in a very lively (and I do say; probably a bit exaggerated) school environment. One other thing to note is the fantastic soundtrack which helps set the scene very well.

												Awesome game! It doesn't get the credits it should deserve. I highly recommend it.Story is entertaining. You play the character of Jimmy Hopkins on his journey in Bullworth Academy. Attending classes, doing jobs and errands for people. Fighting of different gangs to earn their respect and eventually control them. Once you progress in the story line you unlock more of the town around the academy. It feels like GTA but on a smaller scale and without extensive violence. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Let's face it, this game is THE forgotten master piece by Rockstar. You don't have gore in this game, although I would not recommend it for kids, since it does include violence. You go to school as Jimmy Hopkins who has been known as a Bully and has been to several schools, by whom he has been kicked out. Now he is at a Boarding School in New England and whilst you can go to class and do a lot of fun minigames there, such as Music, Biology, Sports, etc.. (I am not kidding they are actually really fun!), you can also later on explore the town around the school and unlock several unique and funny save locations. Even when you complete the game, which has quite a lot of missions, there are still so many things you can do! You can either collect all the Rubber Bands, Trade Cards, or just do some Boxing and Races, win some prices at the carnival, or do whatever pleases you!I have an Xbox Wireless Controller, and it works great! Also the English Language is fully supported, even though Steam says otherwise. Even though some argue that this game was better on the Play Station, for me it is quite the same experience and if you play with a controller, you can really get into this game!Graphics: 9/10 - This Edition is basically the HD edition of the old games, which still has pretty good graphic even though it came out several years ago.Keyboard/Controller Support: 10/10 - I have had loads of fun playing with my controller, and keyboard/Mouse works also.Story: 9/10 - A very good story, which is sadly a bit predictable (taking over the school and stuff)Minigames: 10/10 - A lot of satisfying minigames, which you can engage several times and still have fun with!All in all: One of my favorite games of all time, which for me is even better than most of the GTA Franchise, and for this small price, it is also more than definitely it's money worth!PS: I am still hoping for a Sequel, Rockstar please make it happen!

The stats in the game doesn't really leave out any details of what some people might wanna see and wants to tell their friends who also played this game or compare it with them. This game is very great and recommended to those who miss out their School days. When I was trying to buy this game, I was thinking really hard if it was going to be good or not. I didn't want to look at the reviews of what people put because there was probably going to be spoliers I don't want to see. So I took my chance and got the game definitley didn't regret on getting this game. One of the Best Games that takes to a different level in most of the games you'll probably played before 2008. The graphics and the audio is okay. There's certain parts of when it crashes. So, you'll have to save most of the time. This part is important though, If you wanted the multiplayer version, you'll have to get it for the console. The Computer/Steam Version doesn't have Multiplayer. If you're not sure that you want to buy this game, then you can talk to me about what your not sure about the game. Thanks for reading my review and have wonderful Morning/Evening/Afternoon/Night. :D

												One of Rockstars hidden gems.  This game originally was released in the PS2 era in the UK as Canis Canem Edit (Dog eat Dog), but was also known as Bully. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												I've wanted to play this game a while, but the performance, presentation and general graphical quality of this port leave much to be desired. My eyes physically hurt from looking at the (lack of) antialiasing, and there is no option to turn the graphics quality up - in fact, there are no graphics options beyond "brightness" and "subtitles". I normally don't get hung up on the graphical quality of games, but this... this looks and feels as if I'm playing a PC game from about thirteen or fourteen years ago, right down to the Star Wars: Dark Forces style blocky washed-out menus. That would be kind of acceptable on its own, but the game also runs terribly, chugging along at a paltry rate, and the controls are godawful. I think I might just get this on X-box, where it belongs.

												Some people complain about the crappy controls and outdated graphics.The controls you could get used to (minus shop class, there is no way in hell that one has even been thought through), and the graphics aren't too shoddy, considering the game's age. It's not beautiful in any way, but it's definitely not an eyesore (AA helps).The game itself is amazing. The gameplay, setting, and story are all incredible, and the soundtrack is so damn good you'd wonder why Shawn Lee doesn't do movie scores. A nice additon is that the soundtrack is sitting in your game files in case you want the music from the game. Not all the game music is there though, unfortunately.This is an amazing game, and don't miss out if it's on sale, even if it's enough of a steal at $15.

Posted: May 11, 2013
												Minor Theft Bicycle? Bully plays a lot like a tamer, school yard GTA, but I liked it. I had a lot fun playing through Bully. The missions were usually fun and somewhat varied and the humor was often solid. It's one of the the better GTA clones around.  It took a little over 20 hours to beat and I got about an 80% completion rate.  The graphics look really dated at this point as they are essentially last-last-gen now, but they are still functional. If you like the open-world sandbox game, give Bully a shot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												Imagine your typical GTA game set in a school and you'll get Bully. Contrary to the name, this is not a game where you play the bully. The game begins after Jimmy Hopkins was unceremoniously dumped on the doorsteps of Bullworth academy, after having being expelled from seven other schools. As Jimmy, you'll be forced to fend yourself against the unsavory elements of the school... The scholarship edition offers more missions and classes compared to the console version. The geography class is especially helpful if you're interested in completing the game fully as it provides the location of collectibles. The only drawback with this port is that the controls while on bicycles are overly sensitive. This can, however, be circumvented by using a pc controller.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 15, 2011
												Encompassing all the mythos that American high schools have been endowed by the media throughout the last century, Bully: Scholarship Edition serves as a reminder of other times where rivalries and pranks were taken on the physical plane rather than internet chat logs and micspams. For more practical information, this port was not perfect when it was first released but most issues have been fixed since then. This is an expanded version of the original release, with more variety of classes, characters, missions, and a revised storyline.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 7, 2013
												Probably Rockstar's best game on the PC, it's the only one of their sandbox adventure game's I've completed.  You play as an adolescent teen trying to make his way through a year at a bording school.  The missions are varied and there are a ton of little touches that bring the game to life.  One really cool thing that's easy to miss is that every single student NPC is unique and will react to you based your path through the game.  Recommended only if you have a controller, because some of the challeneges are downright impossible on a keyboard.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												Bully proved to be an open-ended world with more depth than is first apparent.  While there are a few bugs and issues, the game has far more joyous mayhem as you slowly build and lose factions with groups.  Powering up health by snogging -- even in some cases being able to get gay kisses -- is very cool.  News has come out that Bully 2 may be in slow development, which would be great news.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 8, 2011
												For GTA fans (III+ and above),  this game is worthy of your time.  It's less violent and bloody of course, but so sweet in it's own unique gameplay too.  I wasn't sure about it at first, but now I'm really happy I'm trying it out now.  It's way more in-depth with tons of stuff to do than I expected.  Your not just limited to some school either, you explore a whole damn city with tons of regions to unlock as your progress in the story to leave a pretty solid open sandbox world to explore!  Anyone who loved all the GTAs cannot pass on Bully.  Disregard what some people might say about the controls on the PC, they aren't difficult to pick up at all.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 23, 2013
												Eh, as a game, it's very good at integrating mundane activities into the player experience. In terms of the whole gameplay experience, there were a few things that just made me lose interest fast, chiefly the inability to retry a mission after failing it. In most games, when you fail a mission, even if it's a side thing, you get a screen that pops up saying "oh, you failed! Want to try again?", but in this one you're booted right back to free roam. Often, the missions can only be found at specific times of day, forcing you to roam around doing stuff that you might have found fun before, but which suddenly becomes tiresome clutter as you claw your way back to a second crack at the mission. summary: don't buy as an in-between time wasting game. This one demands your attention, something I couldn't give it, but a person who likes GTA might jump right in.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												It's clear that Bully: Scholarship Edition is not my favorite game, but at the same time, I feel like you are missing out on a good experience if you have not played this game. The Scholarship Edition has added missions, NPCs, classes, and items to the game, however, in my opinion, they are not worth re-buying the game if you have already completed the older version on the Ps2. The graphics may not be the prettiest you’ve ever seen, and the controls surely aren’t going to be your favorite, but the pure amount of detail and time that went into this game shouldn’t be ignored or looked past. Upon release, this game was already at a disadvantage due to being released on the Ps2 after the newer generation had already started, and Xbox 360 games were on the rise. All that being said, I must admit, I do look forward to the hinted(1) sequel(2). Read my full official review here: http://nerdbacon.com/bully-scholarship-edition-pc/

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 12, 2012
												Despite Bully being originally a PS2 game and therefore it being riddled with glitches this is a really awesome Sandbox game. Basically it's GTA in a school setting and of course the crimes are a lot less severe. This game is tons of fun, the characters are lively and colourful and the stereotypical groups (Nerds, Preps, Greasers, Jocks, Townies, Prefects) are well defined as the main story has you, Jimmy Hopkins, deal with these groups and has you climb to the top of the school to eventually face your nemesis Gary Smith, a sociopathic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who causes trouble behind the scenes. The main story gives you a good variety of missions to do and you can also interact with others in a variety of ways in a very lively (and I do say; probably a bit exaggerated) school environment. One other thing to note is the fantastic soundtrack which helps set the scene very well.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												Like GTA, but in high school and with a lot more hand to hand combat.In other worlds, sandbox world with a lot of stuff to do, collect or beat up.You get "toys" that in no way resemble actual guns and weapons to use to your leisure.Mini-games, QTEs galore.Story: you are a strong kid, that does what others tell him, but are still blamed because you did what you ware told to do.You can be a bully, but it basically all boils down to a lot of misunderstandings, that will make people attack you and give you a reason to beat them all up, until you atchive peace.Good game, a lot of side content, GTA in heart.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												I absolutely love this game, despite of me playing it as a child on the PlayStation 2 (nostalgia) it's like Grand Theft Auto, but you're in a school and you can't kill someone.Instead of lethal weapons, you get a Slingshot, some firecrackers, stink bomb and more. You can give someone a wedgie, which is hilarious, and you can mess with the nerds and even the douchey jocks that always tries to mess with you with no reason. You get to attend classes, such as Music, English, Art, Physical education, etc. Just like any normal school would have.There is a curfew at night which means you have to get to your dorm before it gets dark. You can make out with a girl and get them to make out with you which is pretty useless but I guess if you don't know what porn is, then this might be satisfying for you. What I do when I'm bored is I sneak into the girl's dorm, you know just for fun, and I can ultimately tell that the Girl's dorm looks way classier than the boys' dorm.. The Boys' dorm is filled with trash, boring wallpapers and rats running around. Whilst the girls' dorm looks like a mansion.What's also fun to do is to go outside the school, after completing early missions, you get permission to go outside - where there is actual police trying to catch you if you do something wrong - which makes it look just like Grand Theft Auto. This game is just so much fun and brings so much memories when I used to play it on the Playstation 2.9/10

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												This game was released by Rockstar a long old time ago before we had our GTA 5 and Red Dead Redemption, and if this isn't one of the most fun games I've ever played I don't know what is (PS2 Version). You go through the life of Jimmy Hopkins, a young kid popular for being an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but the game isn't called bully for that reason. You go through Jimmy's life trying to become a better person while trying not to fail your chemistry quiz. It's a great game and really puts school into a game well.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												Not exactly what I was expecting. I thought that this is a milder version of Postal but it is not. For me this is an advanture game with sandbox and RPG mixed in. Violence is not pointless, NPCs are interesting and the gameplay is really diverse. This might not be as complex as GTA San Andreas or GTA 5 but still one of the best Rockstar games (better than GTA 4 IMHO).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												Great nostalgia for me, who played it on ps2. It's a very nice open world rpg. The world has the right size in my opinion, you can discover a lot of places and the environment feels right. My main complaints are due to the port to PC. Some of the minigames are barely doable first try because of the wierd buttons you have to press for them. Translating the rotation of a stick to the circle movement of a mouse is really bad for a quicktime event. I also encountered some bugs, which almost softlocked me out of progression. I basacally had to do a quest, where I throw snowballs at some kids and every time I tried to do it in one go the game froze. I did it eventually by Alt+tabing out of the game after every throw on a kid. Also towards the end the missions get very repetetive.
